messages.content: Hi there. I‚Äôve been having trouble with my phone‚ÄîI can‚Äôt seem to send any picture messages for the past few hours. It‚Äôs really worrying me because I need to send some photos of my grandkids. Can you help me get this fixed, please?

I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre running into that‚Äîlet‚Äôs get picture messaging working again.

To get started, I need to locate your account. Please share one of the following:
- Your phone number
- Your customer ID
- Your full name and date of birth (YYYY-MM-DD)

Once I have that, we‚Äôll run a quick check on your line and then I‚Äôll guide you through a few simple steps on the phone to fix MMS.
messages.reasoning_content: I need to identify the customer first before troubleshooting. Then guide the user through MMS diagnostics: check_status_bar, check_network_status, check_apn_settings, check_network_mode_preference, check_wifi_calling_status, can_send_mms, and check_app_permissions for messaging. Apply fixes per tech policy as needed: ensure mobile data on, correct APN/MMSC, suitable network mode (not 2G), toggle Wi-Fi Calling off if interfering, grant storage/SMS permissions, reboot after APN changes. Also verify line not suspended and data not exhausted by checking line details via customer lookup. Ask for phone number or full name + DOB to locate the account.

messages.content: Okay. My phone number is 555-123-2002 and my name is John Smith. What do I do now?

messages.reasoning_content: Identify the customer using the provided phone number to get customer and line IDs. Then verify basic connectivity (cellular signal, mobile data) and MMS status. Follow tech support policy: check cellular service, then mobile data, then MMS prerequisites (APN MMSC, network mode not 2G, Wi-Fi Calling off, messaging app permissions). After checks, guide the user through appropriate diagnostic and fix actions via the available user-side tools.

Thanks, John. I‚Äôve located your account and the line for 555-123-2002. It‚Äôs active, which is good. Now let‚Äôs run a few quick checks on your phone to pinpoint what‚Äôs stopping picture messages.

Please let me know the results for each of these checks. You can tell me what you see, or I can run them for you if you prefer I walk you through it:

1) Status bar
- Do you see any signal bars, and does it show something like 5G, 4G/LTE, or 3G?
- Is there an airplane icon? Is mobile data enabled?

2) Mobile data is on
- In Settings, confirm Mobile Data is turned on.

3) SIM status
- Is the SIM detected and active? (No ‚Äúmissing‚Äù or ‚Äúlocked‚Äù messages.)

4) Network mode
- Is your phone set to 5G/4G, or is it on 2G/3G?

5) APN settings
- Are the APN and MMSC set correctly? If you‚Äôre unsure, we can reset them to defaults.

6) Wi‚ÄëFi Calling
- Is Wi‚ÄëFi Calling turned on? If yes, we can try turning it off temporarily, as it sometimes interferes with MMS.

7) Messaging app permissions
- Does your messaging app have permission to access storage and SMS?

8) Test MMS
- Can you try sending a small photo now and tell me what error you see, if any?

If you‚Äôd like, I can guide you step-by-step through checking each of these. Let me know which option you prefer.
messages.reasoning_content: Proceed with device-side diagnostics for MMS on the user‚Äôs phone using the available diagnostic actions. Start with status bar, network status, SIM, data restriction, APN, network mode, and can_send_mms, then decide fixes.

messages.content: That‚Äôs a lot to check, and I‚Äôm a little flustered just looking at it! Could you please walk me through one thing at a time? I get confused easily with all these steps. Maybe, could we start with whatever you think is easiest?

Absolutely‚Äîlet‚Äôs take it one small step at a time. We‚Äôll start with the simplest thing.

Step 1: Make sure Mobile Data is turned ON
- Open your phone‚Äôs Settings.
- Go to Connections or Network & Internet (the exact name can vary slightly).
- Find Mobile Data and make sure it‚Äôs switched ON.

Once you‚Äôve checked that, please let me know whether Mobile Data was already on or if you turned it on. After that, we‚Äôll do the next easy step together.
messages.reasoning_content: Start with the simplest, least intrusive step: confirm Mobile Data is ON in the device‚Äôs network settings. This directly impacts MMS and is easy for the user to check. After they confirm, proceed to check status bar next.

Step 2: Make sure Airplane Mode is OFF

- If you see an airplane icon, Airplane Mode is on.
- If you do see it, please open Settings > Connections (or Network & Internet) and toggle Airplane Mode OFF.

I understand the frustration‚Äîlet‚Äôs keep it simple. The next quick step that often helps is a full restart.

- After it comes back on, wait 30 seconds.

messages.content: I get really nervous restarting my phone. If I do this, is there any chance I‚Äôll lose my pictures or messages? I really can‚Äôt risk losing the photos of my grandkids. Can you reassure me about what will happen?

A restart is completely safe‚Äîit won‚Äôt delete any of your photos or messages. It just refreshes the phone‚Äôs software, like turning a computer off and on. Everything you care about stays exactly where it is.

If you‚Äôre still worried, I can stay with you step-by-step while we do it, and we‚Äôll only move forward when you‚Äôre comfortable. Would you like to proceed with the restart now, or should we try a different simple step instead?

Step 5: Make sure your phone is using 4G or 5G (not 2G)
- Look at the top of your screen. Do you see 5G, 4G, LTE, 3G, or 2G next to the signal bars?

Step 6: Make sure your messaging app has permission to access storage
- Open Settings > Apps > Messaging (or the name of your messaging app).
- Tap Permissions.

You‚Äôre doing a thorough job‚Äîthanks. Let‚Äôs check one important setting that‚Äôs often behind picture message problems.

Step 7: Check APN settings (and reset if needed)
- Open Settings > Connections > Mobile Networks > Access Point Names (APN).
- Look for an entry that is selected or has a dot/checkbox next to it.
- It should show an APN name and an MMSC URL (often starts with http://mms or something similar).
- If you‚Äôre unsure whether it looks right, we can reset APN to the correct defaults.

Easiest option: Reset APN
- In the APN menu, tap the menu button (three dots) and choose Reset to default.
- After it resets, restart your phone.
- Then try sending the photo again.

Please let me know:

Step 9: Reseat the SIM card
- Power your phone off completely.
- Open the SIM tray using the SIM ejector tool or a small paperclip.
- Take the SIM card out, inspect it for obvious damage or misalignment, then place it back in the tray the same way it came out.
- Reinsert the tray, turn your phone on, wait 30 seconds, and try sending the photo again.

John, thanks for staying with me through all those steps. I think I‚Äôve found the likely cause: your data plan has a monthly limit of 15 GB, and your line is showing about 15.1 GB used. When you reach the limit, data-dependent services like picture messaging can stop working.

We can fix this in one of two ways:
1) Refuel data for this month
- We can add up to 2 GB at $2 per GB. Even a small 0.5 GB or 1 GB refuel would restore connectivity so you can send photos right away.
- How much would you like to add? (Options: 0.5 GB, 1 GB, 1.5 GB, 2 GB)

2) Change to a plan with more data
- If you expect to use more than 15 GB regularly, we can switch you to a higher-data plan for future months.

Which option would you prefer? If you choose refueling, tell me the amount and I‚Äôll process it for you.
